review_title: Get your hours and get out
job_title: Outpatient Therapist in North Hills, CA
pros:
- Get your pre-licensed hours FAST
- Meaningful work with underserved population
- Work with amazing therapists and case managers
- After working here paperwork at any other job will be easy.
Would only recommend to someone fresh out of grad school who wants to get their hours quickly.
cons: You get your hours fast because you are working at least 50 hours a week to meet productivity. Never ending pressure from supervisors to meet productivity with no empathy for reasons why you might not be making productivity (i.e discharged several clients in one month, clients on school breaks). Once you've learned the standard EBPs your clinical skills development becomes stagnant. Supervision primarily focused on billing and paperwork, not clinical skills. High turnover. Benefits package pretty standard and minimum. I felt like I was viewed as entirely disposable. Tons of nepotism. Encouraged to use my PTO when at risk of not meeting productivity for the month.

pros: Teamwork and Collaborations are on point
cons: Many deadlines so you must stay on top of your documentations.

job_title: Clinical Supervisor in North Hills, CA
pros:
Supervisors really care about front-line workers.
Very transparent salary structure - everyone is treated the same.
Lots of training opportunities and encouragement to take advantage of same.
Very friendly and warm culture (I would still be there if I lived in the LA area).
Frequent and consistent recognition of people for going 'above and beyond.'
Tremendous satisfaction at making a positive impact on lives.
cons:
These are all common to DMH contractors:
- A lot of paperwork requiring very exacting detail.
- Service time requirement that requires 50+ hours a week to fulfill.
- Requires a lot of hustle to see all of your clients - this is not an office job.
- Very high stress due to severity of problems facing clients.

review_title: Great co-workers, work half at office half on field.
pros: Very busy with TBS cases. No one call, no responding to crisis.
cons: Months of Nov, Dec not that many hours. Hard having consults with wraparound team.

pros: Overall a great opportunity to build meaningful connections with youth and assist them in transitioning them back into the community and home. I have been foturnate to work with great staff and have a great team to support me.
cons: Therapist burnout due to the need to have a high direct client contact during the week and DMH paperwork expectations, along with other documents to submit in a short amount of time. Some of the youth experience challenges with opening up and at times behaviors are tolerated without providing any consequences.

pros: Great hours, new warehouse, great supervisor
cons: Lots of people coming and going

pros: The atmosphere, my supervisor, lots of training and support
cons: The documentation but it’s the same or better then other places I have worked that contract with the county.

review_title: AWFUL place to work.  Look somewhere else
pros: Salary, peers are supportive, good purpose and mission.
cons: Managers are terrible, everything they do is for show, looks good on paper. Managers get involved in clinical decisions when they haven't been practicing in years or aren't even licensed (just got the Master's in MFT in order to move up the ranks). Cliques, favoritism.

pros: If you like working to help people its the right place for you.
cons: Workload can be very demanding.

review_title: Great staff, but disconnected, cliquish and biased upper management.
job_title: Residential Therapist in North Hills, CA
pros: The staff are supportive, passionate and well trained.  They truly care about supporting each other and providing excellent care to the kids that stay there.   Incentive money is available for exceeding productivity minimums.  Dept managers are supportive, available around the clock and provide great supervision.
cons: Upper management definitely has favorites and there is nepotism among the executive team.  While they provide town hall meetings  for employees, they are reluctant to answer direct questions and often make vague promises.  They are disconnected from the staff that work with the kids... for example, they designed cubicle working space for therapists, social workers, other staff without considering the needs of a functional workspace. They are cramped, some have limited leg space due to shelving placed under the work top, and the chairs bump into the walls of the cubicle of staff moves 6 inches either way. When approached by numerous staff to ask about different accommodations or removal of shelves, staff were told it was too expensive and they could work at a coffee shop. This is only one example, but demonstrates a lack of caring about employee retention, satisfaction and safety.

pros: Excellent services providers and support staff. Competitive compensation for many positions and room to grow.
cons: Same as with any community mental health providers with county contracts- paperwork, changes in expectations, and difficulty with work/life balance.

job_title: Criminal Justice Professional in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good for therapists that want to work at a non-profit organization.
cons: High cost medical benefits, high turn over for therapists

pros: The fellow therapists are incredible, hard-working people who commit to client care and are solid colleagues and supportive individuals. The clinical supervisors are good people, but because of ridiculous demands and responsibility, their focus is administrative and punitive rather than clinical. Working with the clients is quite rewarding. I have some incredible clients and families.
cons: The management team, although well-intentioned, really haven't the slightest clue what their staff goes through on a daily basis. Rather than focusing on client care, the management focuses on productivity and audit-proofing charts, with an extremely punitive environment. Direct service providers are burnt out, overworked, not listened to or supported and many are anxious and in fear of losing their jobs. This is unfortunate as they work unbelievably hard and are passionate about their work and clients. Clinical supervisors are fine, but could do better if allowed to actually do their jobs and conduct clinical supervision rather than administrative deadlines and unrealistic expectations.

job_title: Foster Care Case Manager in Lancaster, CA
pros: Good coworkers, ni clean place.
cons: No cons, it was a good place.

pros: I have been working here for over 5 years and since my first interview, I felt like I was at home. There is so much great supervision and support at the Lancaster office, but you can also feel the passion that The CEO and executive team have for this company and for helping the community. The staff are pleasant to work with and the location differential is very appreciated. You get great experience here while collecting your hours. I also have had the privilege of getting a lot of training that has made me a better professional and a better person.
cons: Let's face it, community mental health is a rough field, but I know that the supervisory team in Lancaster works hard to keep morale high to help ease the ups and downs of this field. I can't think of any cons of this company.

review_title: The worst company I have worked for
pros: The company has decent salaries for the nonprofit world. They promote from within too. They hire good hard working people.
cons: This is a sweat shop of mental health. Overwhelming paperwork is demanded without sufficient administrative support. They dump more and more work every day on their workers. They make your responsible for work that is not supposed to be in your job description. They do not care to hear from people and their needs. They do not provide you what you need to do your job, but expect you to “make it work” as you know.

pros: Their is a change possibility you will be able to impact a child's life in a positive way. Overtime available for those that enjoy working overtime.
cons: The executive do not invest in their program and it's effectiveness. Only ways to increase revenue for themselves and the company. Employees that do care are forced to watch children slide down a destructive path because the executive and many other staff have came to the conclusion that not investing in the kids is simply easier

job_title: Outpatient Therapist in North Hills, CA
pros: During my time working at Penny Lane I really enjoyed the population I worked with. The children and families presented with a great need for services, and demonstrated high motivation to improve their lives, well-being, and relationships.
cons: Penny Lane is a numbers driven agency which lead to  unreasonable expectations from management.  Between extremely large case loads, extreme amounts of paper work, and extreme micro-management, morale among the therapists was low and burnout was high.  While working here it felt like management cared very little about the client's and very much about bringing in as much money as they could.

pros: The pay is not bad for non profit work.  The employee class is pretty easy to work with.
cons: Management is totally related and unless you are in their "IN" crowd they don't want to hear what you have to say.  They say they look at the big picture.  They only look at the aspects of big picture they want to see.

review_title: Worst child care organization that i have work for.
pros: No work-life balance. You need to have your time off approved, which no other co-worker will cover you. 10-12 hours a day working with kids or have all the power to do whatever they want. Rules are grey, so you can get fired at anytime. This is an at-will employment, they will let you go for whatever reason, and will fight you over unemployment at all cost. You will never move up the ladder unless you brown nose or are a family member.
cons: I am sorry there were pro's?

review_title: great place for hours, thats about it.
pros: You get your hours done quickly. Supportive co-workers who become your closest friends.
cons: Your usual work week is over 50 hours a week, with no overtime compensation. You usually work on your weekends to catch up on paperwork. Push for paperwork and billing instead of focussing on client needs. You are threatened with write-ups, even when you don't meet productivity due to client cancellations (out of your control).

cons: They will work you very hard so you will earn every penny they pay you and then some. Management cares about management the rest end up having to deal with that. They will ask employees what they think only to do what they want anyway.

review_title: A great company that does great work!

pros:
The CEO makes great attempts to interact and collaborate with the direct care employees. They blur the line of the great difference in pay and give much praise to those who are doing the direct work. 

They offer competitive pay!
cons: In light of risk, there is usually a new form that is implemented to prevent incidents. There is minimal processes for removing outdated forms, leading to so much paperwork to complete. This affects ratio and ability to manage time effectively.

review_title: Demoralizing even on a good day!
job_title: Staff Therapist in North Hills, CA
pros: The best reasons were the kids who this agency serves.  Nothing else comes close.
cons: The staff here were condescending, the supervisors were incompetent, and more interested in their paychecks than serving the kids in the surrounding area.  I never worked in an agency with such short-sighted, and narcissistic therapists! At times it was as if the inmates were running the asylum. I would never recommend this agency to anyone whatsoever. I left and found a much better position where I am treated with respect and valued for my insights. Penny Lane is pathetic!

review_title: My experience at Penny Lane was unique and challenging
pros: Good company to gain entry level experience. Large organization within the non-profit Group Home sector.
cons: Value of employees based primarily on factors other than quality of work, ability, and education. Cultural and value flaws.

pros: Dubnoff Center was a GREAT place to work; supportive administration, open-door policies, room for advancement and numerous options for employees.
cons: Dubnoff Center is no longer in existence; it was taken over by Penny Lane and most administrative staff were relieved of their duties.

review_title: Not a good place to move forward
job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Hills, CA
pros:
- Occasional bonuses (see cons for why this isn't as great as it seems....)
- Generally pretty friendly staff
cons:
This company is mismanaged from top to bottom. Support staff is often overlooked and under appreciated. Managers in all departments (except a couple) think they are the only department that matters and this gives them a very false sense of entitlement and this comes from the very top. Often times it feels that there are more meetings about how to help the clients than actual work helping the clients. 

Money tends to  be mismanaged like it's nobody's business - spending tens/hundreds of thousands on irrelevant things that do not really help the company move forward and don't help provide better support for the clients who are in need.

Pay was a joke and knowledge was irrelevant. The semi-regular bonuses that my department received did nothing but boost me to a level that brought me in line with what I should've been making with my experience and skill set. Received my annual COL raise 6 months late, and it was presented to me as a favor and as a reward for a job well done, when it was less than $1 an hour. Other members of my team with less experience/less knowledge were making significantly more simply because they were the bosses favorites. On a regular basis, I was expected to work overtime without additional pay, and often times was paid when I was not in the office (sick), and that was used as the reason for me working on a Saturday without pay.

As a whole, Penny Lane was one of the most unprofessional businesses I have ever worked at. There were 9 staff in my new hire training course when I started, and within 3 months, myself and 1 other remained. Now there are none of us, and this is a fairly regular occurrence. Every two weeks, at least 4-6 new employees were on-boarded, and 3-4 left the company. Knowledge and work ethic mean nothing - they look for people to fill seats. When when given ample proof of the inability for staff to complete the job they were hired for, no write ups occur and there is 0 repercussions for not knowing how to do your job.

pros:
-Location stipend (at Antelope Valley location only)
-Individual office (at the Lancaster location with the exception of the MAT assessors)
-friendly/supportive coworkers
-A few supervisors are willing to put the needs of clients ahead of revenue when needed
-EBP trainings are available (although the company began to limit trainings during my tenure)
cons: The Cons outweigh the Pros by a wide margin. There are several aspects of the agency that work really well (mostly at the corporate office) however, the Antelope Valley location seems to operate on a different planet as the rest of the agency. Most agencies have billing requirements and provide encouragement for staff to meet expectations. This agency is punitive and employs expectations that are not possible to meet (i.e. upon starting, a new-hire receives 2 large binders filled with information, must read through over 30 regulations that could lead to the equivalent of a write-up). It appears that Client care doesn't even get the backseat (the trunk is probably most accurate) where a therapist will be expected to constantly shift clients' billing plan (which creates additional paperwork) even if the client does not meet the criteria. The morale is pretty low; In the 6 months I was there, I noticed at least 7 therapists get hired and either resign or transfer to a different location. If you happen to be looking for opportunities to advance your career, the Lancaster location is not the place. In interviews, I was told there were "plenty" of opportunities for advancement however, after being hired and discussing this with my supervisor, I was informed that it was not likely that a promotion would happen within a year and highly unlikely to become a clinical supervisor (even if you meet qualifications). Lastly (and probably most importantly), upper-management (including clinical supervisors) have "favorites." If you happen to be a favorite, the job seems to be less intense. If you do not happen to be a favorite (or fit into what the identify as a "family" environment), upper management applies an exorbitant amount pressure and become quick to create a paper trail that could eventually lead to being fired. Overall, there are no real benefits to working for the company. As previously mentioned, the cons significantly outweigh the pros. Even if you are just out of school, it would be more worth your time to find an agency (or practice) that practice good values and set realistic expectations (there are definitely a few out there!).

review_title: In support of the support staff
